text: Queen's service medal which was announced yesterday and in the awards lists well done and I think I speak for the whole committee when I say it's a an acknowledgement of your years and years of service which was really something that our community can be proud of having you with us for you know there it's people like you and and your your associates who make our communities what they are and  And certainly it's been a long time coming, Hazel. So congratulations. Oh, thank you.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Thank you very much.
speaker: hazelbarnes

text: And I think Gary and maybe even Jim wanted to say a few words.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Oh.  I was going to defer to His Worship, but yes, thank you, Hazel, for everything you've done. I've been in Council for a long time. I think you've been there just about as long in one way or another. But look, thank you sincerely, the people of Kihiki, folks in Grey Power, folks associated with all those wonderful developments you've been spearheading in Kihiki, including the Kihiki domain, the Ratatouille Reserve, all of those things.  so much energy and passion. And so, look, thank you sincerely for everything you've done, both for the council and for the staff at Waipā.
speaker: garrydyet

text: Oh, thank you. Thank you, Gary. Thank you. But, you know, it didn't happen without you, too. Sorry, Jim.
speaker: hazelbarnes

text: Look, just confirming sort of Gary's comments, Hazel, but we have spoken, but yeah, huge congratulations from me.  look, a fantastic life of service. I really was blown away by the resume, I suppose, that was put together for the award and the amount of service that you've given, not only from a council perspective, but to the community was absolutely huge. So, a huge congratulations from me and it's great to be able to  pass on those best wishes without it being as your daughter was putting together your nomination and talking to you as if it was your eulogy. So it's great to be able to compliment you without it being in that sort of circumstance. So look, huge congratulations and thanks from the community for everything you've done. Oh, thank you, Jim.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Thank you.  It was a pleasure and an honour to receive it and I think it meant I had to give up some things but the outcomes for the community and the people that actually I worked with just made it all very, very worthwhile. So thanks very much.
speaker: hazelbarnes

text: Great, well done Hazel, congratulations. Thank you Susan.  So without further ado, let's move on to our agenda, which I understand you should all be looking at on our new e-governance platform, Diligence. Have we all found where we should be? Excellent. On the first page there, actually, second page of our agenda, we have two apologies, I believe, Graham and Bruce. Bruce is trapped at Pāwanui, which is terrible. He must be really hating that.  So I have those two apologies. We didn't have any more than that, did we, Jenny? No, just the two. Excellent. And moving on then to disclosures of members' interests. Roger threw his hand up there. So Roger, all those in favour say aye. Aye. Against, carried. Right, moving on to disclosure of members' interests. Do we have any? I don't believe we have any.  Conflicts today, nobody contacted me about that. Excellent. Fantastic. Late items, I'm not aware that there are any late items to be brought up today. So moving on then to the item on our agenda was confirmation of the order of the meeting. Order as I understand it, as it appears in the agenda, I have recommendation there. Is somebody happy to move that for me? Mike and second and Claire, all those in favor, say aye.  aye against carried okay so we'll move on to the confirmation of minutes there on page three as is our usual practice I'll just cite the numbers of the pages of the actual meeting minutes and if somebody has an issue with them they can just alert me to it so that's page four and five six and seven
speaker: susanoregan

text: Susan, on page six, I just wanted to query something. Oh, sorry. It's to do with the newspapers advertising again. I think it's the paragraph numbers one, two, three, four, five, six, and it's the fourth line. Because we had quite a bit of talk about how we would get the message out to the community.  And it's more that the newspapers were being delivered again, you know, because there was a time when they weren't even being produced. Not so much advertising. So I just wondered whether or not we could change that advertising to we're being delivered again. Yeah, that makes sense, because that was what the point was, I think.
speaker: clairestpierre

text: Yeah, I don't think we're taking out advertisements in the newspaper. Yeah. So, Jenny, are we able to change that?  was advised that the newspapers were being delivered again that's fine no I can change that excellent thanks for that clear so then pages 7 & 8 and then 9 & 10 11 & 12  good notwithstanding that one small change that Claire alerted us to so I have a recommendation then appearing on page three that the minutes be circulated read and confirmed as true and correct have I hit anybody's have to move that Marcus thank you seconded Phil all those in favor say aye against carried excellent right moving on then to our first substantive matter  on our agenda, which is the fire control matter. I'm still trying to navigate my way around here. It's appearing on page 13, Amendment to the Fire Control Bylaw 2015. And I believe Graham Pollard is taking us through this matter. Take it away, Graham. Welcome. Yes.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Thank you, Chair. And good morning, everybody. This item is to change a resolution from December 2019's meeting of this committee.  You may recall that the committee resolved to recommend to council adoption of a new fire control bylaw. However, before we could actually bring this to council in December, we got some further legal advice that said that even though we were actually removing about 80% of the bylaw, it was actually an amended bylaw rather than a new bylaw.  is this sort of fine line between when an amendment becomes so big that it's actually a new bylaw. But it's quite important in this case because under the amendments in the Fire and Emergency New Zealand Act that was amending the Local Government Act in terms of consultation, we don't need to consult on this bylaw change if it is an amended bylaw.  but we do if it is a new bylaw. So in the circumstances at the moment, we probably have bigger issues to consult on than some amended clauses of a bylaw. So what we're asking for today is to revoke December's resolution and replacing it with a new resolution  that the committee recommends council adopt an amended fire control bylaw 2015. You've got in the appendices of the report what the amended bylaw will look like. So lots of clauses are showing as deleted. And in the second appendix, you can actually see what is proposed to be taken out because it's no longer part of council's jurisdiction.  Thank you, Chair. Happy to take questions.
speaker: grahampollard

text: All right. Does anybody have any questions or. Yeah, thanks.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Thanks, Graham. We're just a few inconsistencies that I wanted to check out and I didn't have a chance to send them through prior to the meeting. The first is on if you go to the track changes version and the table of contents at the bottom, there's schedules one and two for tyre  vehicle tire storage or something. And they're not deleted from the table of contents, but in actual fact they have been deleted from the body. And I also queried the need for the definition of restricted fire areas. Like I think there's maps at the back that show permanently restricted fire areas for the urban areas or residential areas of the district.  But in actual fact, it only applies for getting permits, and now we don't need to get permits. So I think, I don't know if they need it anymore.
speaker: clairestpierre

text: I recall that we had sent this through Helen Atkins for legal review, and this has come out okay. I can double check on that.
speaker: grahampollard

text: Yeah, yeah, because our bylaw now only deals with nuisance fires.
speaker: clairestpierre

text: Yeah.
speaker: marcusgower

text: Yeah. And so I picked that up on page six of the bylaw. Yeah. And then the last thing was on page 47, which says about actually, you know, the foregoing bylaw has been made by the council by special consultative procedure. Well, we're not following a special consultative procedure now, are we?
speaker: clairestpierre

text: Not in this case, no.  Sorry, if you could direct me to the page again. This is right at the end.
speaker: grahampollard

text: Yeah, on page 14 of the... Through you, Madam Chair, just if I could respond to that point.
speaker: clairestpierre

text: Just that the bylaw itself, the original bylaw made in 2015, did progress through a special consultative procedure.  And this is simply an amendment to it. So that does remain true for the bylaw as a whole. Yeah, that's correct. Thank you.
speaker: manager

text: OK, yeah, so those are the only points.
speaker: clairestpierre

text: OK, thanks for that, Clare. So Graham, are you just able to clarify that with us? In terms of the first matter raised then by Clare?
speaker: susanoregan

text: In terms of the fire permits and the fire areas, yes, I can double check back on that.
speaker: grahampollard

text: Brilliant. Excellent.  Now, Roger, were you waving your hand around? Roger has a question.
speaker: susanoregan

text: I was, and it's Graham, just through you, Madam Chair. Just a clarification, really.  I accept the fact that we've got bigger fish to fry currently and quite happy with the fact that it's an amended bylaw, but it does look a lot messy. Will there be opportunity in the future to clean it up and make it an easy to follow bylaw? Because I think anybody looking at it now would have a difficulty going through all of the amendments and deletions.
speaker: rogergordon

text: Indeed, that's one of the reasons why I would have  I preferred originally to create something separate, but just working on the advice we've got. With all by-laws, there are opportunities to review them further, and we've got a chance to look at this again  in another 10 years time or at any other time. All bylaws have to be reviewed within a maximum of 10 years. So there may be opportunities to bring these provisions into another bylaw in the future as we consolidate things.
speaker: grahampollard

text: What we've got is what we live with. Yeah, OK. Yeah.
speaker: rogergordon

text: It should do the job, which is  one of the main things we're trying to achieve.
speaker: grahampollard

text: Yep.
speaker: marcusgower

text: Thank you, Graeme. Any other questions for Graeme? No, none out there. OK, so I have a recommendation there appearing on page 14, A, B and C. This is obviously to receive the report. B is to revoke part C and D of our earlier resolution of our meeting on the 4th of December.  and further determine that the draft amendment Fire Control By-law 2015 is the most appropriate method and form of addressing Council's fire control responsibilities. And then the third recommendation is to recommend that we approve the proposed amendments to the Fire Control By-law 2015 as set out in Appendix 1. And it's to be effective the 1st of July. Can I have anybody who's happy to move that for me? Marcus and seconded Liz. All those in favour say aye.  Those against? Carried. Excellent. Thank you very much, Graham.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Thank you.
speaker: grahampollard

text: OK, moving on to our next item, which is the district plan work programme, which I believe we have Tony Quickfall here to present for us. So this is appearing on page 63. It starts on page 63 of our agenda.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Good morning Madam Chair, morning Councillors, Your Worship. So this is an update report and probably from this point going forward we'd like to probably take this to the committee on a regular basis just because of a weak programme around plan changes which is fairly ambitious I suppose. So by way of update I'm looking at under item or paragraph three  We've got a district plan work program which comprises of five work streams. So we've got a plan changes, work stream, national planning standards, e-plan, national directions and legislative changes. I'll take the report as read but we'll just take you through a summary if that's okay. So we do have a suite of plan changes which we've  I guess, programmed as different types. So we've got seven do now plan changes, three do next, and at least two private. And just as an example of how the work or this particular work stream is quite agile, there's some updates since this report was written that I'll take you through. So under 3.1, we talk about two plan changes had already been started and underway. There's another two I'd like to add to that. So plan change 15, which is around permeable surfaces.  and plan change 16 which is technical improvements so those ones we're now considering as having been started. Plan change 14 so in the report we talked about notification 2020 slash 2021 as a result of a meeting with a landowner on Friday we're now looking at potentially notifying that one October 2021 so I haven't even had the chance to update our workstream program around that yet so this is an example of how we're quite agile around the space.  So I'll just take those other ones there as read. I'm happy to take questions later on any of those specific plan changes. The do next. So we've got some infill subdivision that we will be looking at. That's quite a big plan change on its own. And also that aligns with the National Planning Standard for Urban Development.  Rather than, well there's two issues around that, we don't have a resource at the moment to commence that, but also the risk of going ahead and doing that now would mean that we may end up with a plan change that we need to change later on once the NPS comes out. So we think it's prudent to hold off on that one. We do have a council plan change on a programme around Māori sites, significance in Papakāinga. So again, quite a body of work around that and that's one that we'll be doing at a later stage.  And the third one is around rezoning, just rationalizing some zoning. The reason that's what I'll do next is because the time frame is a little bit uncertain around those, so we're waiting for other factors to, I guess, advise us and inform us when those might happen. National planning standards. So just a reminder that that's a government requirement where all district plans are reformatted into a consistent standard.  We do have a deadline around that of 2026. We've de-prioritised that at the moment because some of these plan changes we're quite keen to get up and away. So Julie's done a fair bit of work on that already, but that's kind of on hold at the moment. On the 3.3, the ePlan, so again as part of the National Planning Standards, we do have to have an interactive electronic district plan up and running by 2026.  So separately to this report we do have an e-solutions program of work which the council is rolling out, e-plan is part of that. So all going well, we anticipate hopefully that the budget will be confirmed for that through the annual plan and then we can start looking at procurement for an e-plan platform. National directions, there hasn't been a lot of activity with COVID around that nationally, however there's still a couple that we anticipate coming into force  In the next few months, we haven't had any updates from central government around that. So that's around biodiversity, urban development, highly productive soils. And each of those will probably require that we make changes to our plan, mandatory changes without going through a consultative process. And there may be some consequential changes there as well. Just finally, there are three legislative changes that will impact the work programme.  So the first one you may be familiar with is a bill that's progressing under urgency to fast-track some COVID projects around through resource consenting. So there'll be some criteria around there and the process as we understand it's a bill at the moment. The process as we understand it is any applicant with those kind of projects could apply to the Minister.  The Minister makes the determination and if he agrees that the candidates are fast-tracking then they would go through a process that may not even have a hearing. There may be no consultation. So it's quite a streamlined process and the Minister makes a decision around that. Council's involvement in that at the moment is minimal. So if there's an application in a particular area  then the minister can invite someone from the council to be part of that decision-making body and also the minister can invite some feedback from I guess council staff at a technical level but there's no mandate to do that so we'll see where that one ends up. I think Local Government New Zealand has put a submission in asking for a bit more involvement at a local level. There's two other legislative  activities underway so one is the bill to amend the RMA that's coming very close to enactment that reinstates parts that were previously repealed so there's there's no real impact on our business as usual it introduces a new fast track hearing process for freshwater plants which doesn't really affect us directly but it also strengthens enforcement powers so the Environmental Protection Agency will have more powers around enforcement than they haven't had previously  which is a good thing for us because it means if we're in a situation where we need to get some extra support around enforcement, we can shoulder tap the EPA to get some support around that. And the final one is a comprehensive overhaul of the RMA. Some intel from the ministry officials last week was that they're expecting still the technical advisory group to report back July on that, around the recommendations and then a cabinet paper will follow. So that's still on track.  So as you can see, quite an ambitious work program we've got there. Plan changes is our priority at the moment. We're confident we do have the budget and resource to manage that, but we'll need to keep quite a close eye on how that's tracking through the process. And happy to take questions.
speaker: tonyquick

text: Thanks very much, Tony. Yeah, you're right. It's a pretty ambitious work plan, but I'm sure with your motivated team, you'll knock it off one by one. Claire, have you a question there?
speaker: susanoregan

text: Yeah. Thanks, Susan.  Tony, I'm really happy with the programme as it stands, and I think that you've got a great team there working really hard for us. The question I have is not particularly related to those issues, but more that in Auckland, there's been a thing about water tanks or rainwater tanks, and that they are classified as a building, you know, under the unitary plan, and so people need resource consent. So what's the situation in Waipa if people wanted to put a tank in there? There are those sort of hurdles that people face here, aren't there?
speaker: clairestpierre

text: I don't know what I don't know the building act well enough to know what the requirements of the building act are around but I do know you can get slimline tanks that aren't classified as a building so I'd be thinking that there's options for people to put in water tanks if they want to. I don't think there's any impediments in our district plan for doing that but there's also no compulsion so we don't require people to do that.
speaker: tonyquick

text: Yeah okay thank you. It just seemed to be a topical thing and like I think Auckland Council's coming under fire because they've made it difficult  in the past for people to take that kind of sensible action to conserve the water. So, you know, I suppose that they don't need to take so much from water care. And I just wonder how we replaced things. Yeah.
speaker: clairestpierre

text: Thanks, Claire. Does anybody else have any questions for Tony? No. Excellent. Right. So on page 63 itself, we just have the one recommendation there just to receive Tony's  report title District Plan Work Programme. Andrew, happy to move. Phil, happy to second. All those in favour say aye. Aye.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Against.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Carried. Excellent. Thanks very much, Tony. Best of luck with that. Right, moving on to the next item, which appears on page 69 of our agenda, which is the Ratatou Renaming  item and I believe we have Anna McElrey here for this. Good morning Anna. Mōrena, thank you Madam Chair, mōrena koutou.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Look this is a project that started before my time and is well underway in terms of the enhancement works and getting those all done for the New Zealand War commemorations in October.  Luckily, with level four, we were still able to progress and we're working with archaeologists and Heritage New Zealand to get the necessary approvals to do the works. Rob Sinclair, our project manager, is working hard now and there'll be seeding in spring for those works. When we went to Ngāi Wītōpū at the end of last year to talk to them about the works, Harold Maniapoto raised that the creek name for the area  is actually Tūrata rather than Rata Tū. And he pointed us in the direction of a written reference that's on the Māori Affairs website, which is quoted in the report. And following that, we went to Maniapoto Ki Te Rāki's hui in February. And again, it was confirmed that the correct name, correct traditional name, is Tūrata for the area. We followed up with DOC to confirm what would be the process we'd have to follow to change the name. And they confirmed  that it wouldn't need to be a formal reserves act process given that that name is a name just to identify a number of land parcels and not specifically a reserve name. And so we went to the Te Awamutu community board last month, they endorsed the name change and today we're seeking your approval to make that change. And so that will be for obviously some reserve signage on site, the council website, any information relating to the area.  and also letting our leases and other stakeholders who refer to the area to update them on the name change. So, happy to answer any questions. Thank you, Tina.
speaker: annamcelrea

text: Hazel? I'd like to move the recommendation but also to say that you've gone through all the official channels but there are many senior Māori people here in Kihikihi who will be very pleased to see the name corrected.  They don't have to say it quietly under their breath to us anymore. It's really tūrāta. So I'm absolutely delighted to recommend that this be official.
speaker: hazelbarnes

text: Right, thank you, Hazel. Did anybody have any questions or comments or are people happy to second?
speaker: susanoregan

text: I'll second that motion, Madam Chair.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Marcus or Mike, were you seconding or were you commenting? I have a question.
speaker: susanoregan

text: I just noticed on page 70 of the report that you're going to put a fence around the water tower and remove the shed. Is there any plan for the actual water tower to remove it as well, because it's not a historical thing?
speaker: marcusgower

text: Oh, can I?  Can I make a comment here? Marcus, through you Madam Chair. Marcus, this was discussed a few years ago when it all came up about tidying up that reserve. And yes, it was marked for demolition, but the community raised up on their back legs and said they didn't see why. For them, it was a landmark.  so okay it's not a historic thing there but that was how it stayed in the plan because they're going to remove those old sheds around it and tidy it all up but yeah so we're there you want to revisit that but the community very loudly told us  that they if it didn't if it wasn't causing any harm and it wasn't in anybody's way uh please leave it there fence it off and and so that kids can't go climbing up and when we officially get the park sorted out uh but that's the only reason it that it survived as community demand this might be due for another discussion because the community that i talked to don't actually see it as a significant thing and would much rather have
speaker: hazelbarnes

text: something planted there or something that has more historical connections to the area rather than a concrete water tower that my dad can remember being built.
speaker: marcusgower

text: So, I see you're raising your waving your hand around there. Thank you through the chair.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Back in these service delivery committee meeting, we agreed that this was an initial work that we were doing in terms of the war commemorations that were coming up and that we would look at future items  within the reserve at a later date when there was further funding to do that. So just remembering back to service delivery committee that the decision was based on doing these initial works first. And part of that was just for health and safety reasons that we would be sensing off the water tower until we looked at that again further.
speaker: sallysheedy

text: Yeah. Thank you, Sally. Anna, did you have a comment to make?
speaker: susanoregan

text: Just in addition to what Sally said, part of the scope of works is that we are commissioning an engineering assessment of the water tower, so that will enable those future discussions to understand the costs in retaining it and making it safe, but also costs in removing and re-establishing. Great, thank you Ena.

text: Mike, did you have something to add?
speaker: susanoregan

text: Yeah, it was just a question of understanding, really. For Anna, when you mentioned the stakeholders that have been mentioned with the name change, I'm just wondering, when we make name changes like this to reserves or maybe to lanes or crescents, et cetera, is Google informed in terms of Google Maps and that sort of thing? Is that relevant or not? It was just a general question.
speaker: mikepettit

text: Great question. Yes, very relevant. And I'm not quite sure of the process we need to go through to do that. But we will be updating obviously our map layer. And then I will follow that up as well. Thank you.
speaker: annamcelrea

text: And Marcus.  Actually, Mike, can we borrow your water tower? Because aren't we looking for a new location for that?

text: Save the Cambridge Road Post some money. You can have it for free. Good luck moving it.

text: Have we got any other comments or questions for Anna or Sally on that matter? Because I have Hazel having moved and the name changed. Do I have somebody who's happy to second that?  Marcus, you're happy to second it? All those in favour say aye. Aye. Against? Carried. Well done people. Thank you Anna. Well done.
